case_name: Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Krishnappa and his two sons Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu constituted a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnappa and his two sons - Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu - companystituted a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The family carried on business in mining in the name and style of Krishnappa and Sons.

anchor.surface_text: They carried on business in mining in the name and style of Krishnappa and Sons.

facts.text: The family was disrupted in 1946, and all its properties were divided among the members of the family.

anchor.surface_text: The family was disrupted in 1946, and all its properties were divided among the members of the family.

facts.text: The business of Krishnappa and Sons was taken over by a firm whose partners were Krishnappa and his two sons.

anchor.surface_text: The business of Krishnappa and Sons was taken over by a firm which the partners were Krishnappa and his two sons.

facts.text: A private limited Company styled Krishnappa Asbestos and Barytes Private Ltd. took over the business of the firm on May 21, 1947 for Rs. 2,04,000.

anchor.surface_text: A private limited Company styled Krishnappa Asbestos and Barytes  Private  Ltd. took over the business of the firm on May 21, 1947 for Rs. 2,04,000.

facts.text: Thimmayya obtained employment under the Company as mines superintendent at a monthly salary of Rs. 400.

anchor.surface_text: Thimmayya obtained employment under the Company as mines superintendent at a monthly salary of Rs. 400

facts.text: Venkatanarsu obtained employment under the Company as General Manager at a monthly salary of Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: and Venkatanarsu as General Manager at a monthly salary of Rs. 500.

facts.text: Proceedings for assessment of tax due by the Hindu undivided family for the years 1941-42, 1942-43, 1944-45, 1945-46 and 1946-47 were pending at the time when the Hindu undivided family was disrupted.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings for assessment of tax due by the Hindu undivided family for the years 1941-42, 1942-43, 1944-45, 1945-46 and 1946-47 were pending at the time when the Hindu undivided family was disrupted.

facts.text: On May 20, 1946, Venkatanarsu claimed before the Additional Income-tax Officer, Cuddapah that the property of the Hindu undivided family had been partitioned among the members in definite portions.

anchor.surface_text: On May 20, 1946, Venkatanarsu claimed before the Additional Income-tax Officer, Cuddapah that the property of the Hindu undivided family had been partitioned among the members in definite portions.

facts.text: This claim was not disposed of till June 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons which do number appear from the record, this claim was number disposed of till June 30, 1952.

facts.text: Assessments for the five years in question were made by the Income-tax Officer on diverse dates between September 30, 1948 and November 30, 1950, resulting in a tax liability of Rs. 65,750 in the aggregate.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile assessments for the five years in question were made by the Income-tax Officer on diverse dates between September 30, 1948 and November 30, 1950, resulting in a tax liability of Rs. 65,750 in the aggregate for the five years.

facts.text: Appeals preferred against the orders of assessment to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal proved unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals preferred against the orders of assessment to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal proved unsuccessful.

facts.text: It was common ground that it was not contended in the appeals that in making the orders of assessment, without disposing of the claim that the family was disrupted in 1946, the Income-tax Officer had acted illegally.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that it was number companytended in the appeals that in making the orders of assessment, without disposing of the claim that the family was disrupted in 1946, the Income-tax Officer had acted illegally.

facts.text: On June 30, 1952 the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Madras, made an order under section 25-A recording that the property of the Hindu undivided family of Krishnappa and his sons was partitioned on November 2, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1952 the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Madras, made an order under section 25-A recording that the property of the Hindu undivided family of Krishnappa and his sons was partitioned on November 2, 1946.

facts.text: As the tax due was not paid the Income-tax Officer made an order under section 46(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 on June 25, 1958 calling upon the Managing Director to withhold the amount of tax due from the salaries payable to Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu.

anchor.surface_text: As the tax due was number paid the Income-tax Officer made an order under section 46 5  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 on June 25, 1958 calling upon the Managing Director to withhold the amount of tax due from the salaries payable to the defaulters Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu and to show the same to the credit of the Government of India.

facts.text: Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu lodged petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, praying that writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs be issued quashing the order dated June 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu then lodged petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, praying that writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs be issued quashing the order dated June 25, 1958 of the Income-tax Officer under section 46 5 .

facts.text: The petitions were founded on two grounds: i) that after the Income-tax Officer recorded an order on June 30, 1952 under section 25-A(1) that the family has disrupted with effect from November 2, 1946, steps taken for recovery without an appropriate order under section 25-A(2) were invalid; ii) arrears of tax due by the erstwhile Hindu undivided family could not be recovered from remuneration earned by them as employees of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: They founded their petitions on two grounds -  i  that after the Income-tax Officer recorded an order on June 30, 1952 under section 25-A 1  that the family has disrupted with effect from November 2, 1946, steps taken for recovery of the amount of tax assessed without an appropriate order under section 25-A 2  were invalid and  ii  arrears of tax due by the erstwhile Hindu undivided family companyld number be recovered from remuneration earned by them as employees of the Company.

facts.text: The petitions were decided by Seshachelapati J. in favour of the two petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions were decided by Seshachelapati J., in favour of the two petitioners, and the decision was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: The decision was confirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: and the decision was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Against the order of the High Court, with certificate of fitness, these two appeals have been preferred by the Income-tax Officer, Cuddapah.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the High Court, with certificate of fitness, these two appeals have been preferred by the Income-tax Officer, Cuddapah.

facts.text: The High Court held that the order on the claim made under section 25-A(1) on June 30, 1952 was given a clear retrospective operation, and the Income-tax Officer was bound to give effect to that order recognising the partition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the order on the claim made under section 25-A 1  on June 30, 1952 was given a clear retrospective operation, and the Income-tax Officer was bound to give effect to that order recognising the partition and to follow up the companysequences which flowed from the order.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the order recording partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must be ignored.

anchor.surface_text: Order recording the partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must for reasons aforementioned be ignored and tax levied as if numbersuch order was made.

facts.text: In the absence of an order under section 25-A(1) and consequential proceedings under sub-section (2), liability to pay tax must rest upon the property of the Hindu undivided family; it cannot be enforced against the members personally.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of that step however is that in the absence of an order under section 25-A 1  and the companysequential proceedings under sub-section  2  liability to pay tax must rest upon the property of the Hindu undivided family it cannot be enforced against the members of the family personally.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer has sought by resorting to section 46(5) to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes Private Ltd.; this he was incompetent to do.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer has sought by resorting to section 46 5  to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes  Private  Ltd. this he was incompetent to do.

facts.text: No orders were recorded by the Income-tax Officer at the time of making assessments in respect of the five years, and therefore no personal liability of the members of the family arose under the proviso to sub-section (2).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numberorders were recorded by the Income-tax Officer at the time of making assessments in respect of the five years, and therefore numberpersonal liability of the members of the family arose under the proviso to sub-section  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory assessment procedure is independent of partition claim disposal; jurisdiction unaffected by error or omission.

holdings.text: An order of assessment which has become final is not liable to be re-opened under section 25-A(2) by the Income-tax Officer when an order under section 25-A(1) is passed subsequent to the order of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, in our judgment, in error in holding that an order of assessment which has become final is liable to be re-opened under section 25-A 2 by the Income-tax Officer, when an order under section 25-A 1 is passed by him subsequent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessments finalized through appeals to Tribunal; no machinery to reopen based on later partition order.

holdings.text: Order recording the partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must be ignored and tax levied as if no such order was made.

anchor.surface_text: Order recording the partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must for reasons aforementioned be ignored and tax levied as if numbersuch order was made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finality of assessment orders prevails over subsequent administrative recording of partition.

holdings.text: In the absence of an order under section 25-A(1) and the consequential proceedings under sub-section (2), liability to pay tax must rest upon the property of the Hindu undivided family; it cannot be enforced against the members of the family personally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.25A requires recording of partition before transforming liability to personal joint/several obligation.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was incompetent to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes Private Ltd. under section 46(5).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer has sought by resorting to section 46 5  to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes  Private  Ltd. this he was incompetent to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal salary attachment impermissible without personal tax liability arising under s.25A(2) proviso.

holdings.text: No personal liability of the members of the family arose under the proviso to sub-section (2) of section 25-A as no orders were recorded by the Income-tax Officer at the time of making assessments.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numberorders were recorded by the Income-tax Officer at the time of making assessments in respect of the five years, and therefore numberpersonal liability of the members of the family arose under the proviso to sub-section  2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso activates personal liability only post s.25A(1) order and apportionment; not independent of prior recording.

holdings.text: The proviso to sub-section (2) of section 25-A does not impose joint and several personal liability on members for HUF tax merely upon partition, without recording under sub-section (1).

anchor.surface_text: But howsoever read the proviso yields numbersuch meaning. The scheme of the section is that so long as there is an assessment of the Hindu undivided family, the liability for payment of the tax is on the property of the family and number personally on the members.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading and overall scheme require s.25A(1) order as precondition for proviso's operation.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order confirmed; appeals by Income-tax Officer dismissed with costs; respondents not personally liable for HUF tax; recovery from salaries under section 46(5) invalid without section 25A(2) order.
directions: Income-tax authorities' remedy is to proceed against property of the Hindu undivided family if any
